maml:description.maml:para: Sets the range of IPv6 addresses to exclude from an IPv6 scope.

The Add-DhcpServerv6ExclusionRange cmdlet sets the range of IPv6 addresses to exclude from an IPv6 scope. The IP addresses from this range will not be leased out by the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the IPv6 prefix of the scope to which the exclusion range is being added.
Specifies the starting IP address in exclusion range, as a string formatted as an IPv6 address.
Specifies the ending IP address in exclusion range, as a string formatted as an IPv6 address.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example excludes the IPv6 addresses from 2001:4898:7020:1020::1 to 2001:4898:7020:1020::10 from DHCPv6 scope 2001:4898:7020:1020:: on the DHCP server service running on the local computer.
This example excludes the IPv6 address 2001:4898:7020:1020::1 from the DHCPv6 scope 2001:4898:7020:1020:: on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the IPv6 address ranges excluded from the specified IPv6 subnet prefix.
The Get-DhcpServerv6ExclusionRange cmdlet gets the IPv6 address ranges excluded from the specified IPv6 subnet prefix.
Specifies the IPv6 prefixes of the scopes for which the exclusion ranges are requested.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets all of the IPv6 address ranges which have been excluded from all of the DHCPv6 scopes on the DHCP server service.
This example gets all of the IPv6 address ranges which have been excluded from the specified DHCPv6 scope.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a range of IPv6 addresses previously excluded from an IPv6 scope.

Deletes a range of IPv6 addresses previously excluded from an IPv6 scope. If the StartRange and EndRange parameters are specified, then the exclusion range with the specified starting range and ending range values is deleted. If only the StartRange parameter is specified, then the exclusion range with specified starting range is deleted. If only the EndRange parameter is specified, then the exclusion range with specified ending range is deleted. If neither the StartRange nor EndRange parameter is specified, then all of the excluded IP address ranges present in the specified scope are removed.
Specifies the IPv6 subnet prefix of the scope from which the excluded IP ranges is deleted.
Specifies the starting IPv6 address of the excluded IPv6 range being deleted.
Specifies the ending IPv6 address of the excluded IP range being deleted.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes the excluded IPv6 address range from 2001:4898:7020:1020::1 to 2001:4898:7020:1020::10 from DHCPv6 scope 2001:4898:7020:1020:: on the DHCP server service running on the local computer.
This example deletes the IPv6 address range starting from 2001:4898:7020:1020::1 from DHCPv6 scope 2001:4898:7020:1020:: on the DHCP server service running on computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.

This example deletes the IPv6 address range with ending IP address of 2001:4898:7020:1020::10 from DHCPv6 scope 2001:4898:7020:1020:: on the DHCP server service running on computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.
